displayed_text: Patient: Right. Doctor: Depending on what side. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: They put a needle through – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Doc They take samples out – Patient: Okay! Doctor: And then when you’re done, they say, “Wake up, Mr. L_! You’re goin’ home!” Patient: I’m goin’ home. Doctor: And she’s gonna bring you home! And that’s the end! It’s all outpatient. Patient: Okay. Okay. Family Member: I’m not gonna be there. Patient: Okay. So, doc. So, doc. So, doc.

Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Which is why I think the last conversation was on the vaccine therapy, Provenge. So I know we gave, we gave you all that information. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: I’m not sure he gave it to you? Family Member: No. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: No. He did not. Hum. Doctor: Okay. So did you explain anything to her? Patient: No. She tell me- Family Member: No. But, yes, this is why, right. Yes. This is why I’m here. Doctor: Ah. Okay. Family Member: Because I can’t get a good understanding. Doctor: Okay. Okay. We know the baseline stuff –

Patient: So yeah I’d rather see somebody… Family Member: We burned that bridge. Patient: I’d rather see somebody… yeah can’t go back to that. Doctor: I know because honestly then maybe and that probably should get fixed – Family Member: Yes. Doctor: - even if we make decisions about chemotherapy or something we cannot afford to have a major source of infection sitting right there. So definitely that will hold up a lot of our decisions about other treatments for sure. Family Member: Okay, good. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: If we can get him looked at it’s… Doctor: Well how about any, how is the pain in the neck? Did that flare up? Patient: No. That’s gone. Doctor: That’s been gone too?

Patient: Right, right.. Doctor: Like every single time when you started the first day I met you we’re always behind the cancer. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Stuff happens and I’m reactive. Patient: Stop doctor, we’re not saying that word no more. Doctor: Sorry about that. We’re always behind the thing. Patient: The thing, yes. Doctor: However, what we need to do is get ahead of it. Patient: Right. Doctor: So we’ve got the Provenge in. I think there’s another set of pills, these are FDA approved. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: It is not experimental. Patient: Right.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But you got to see most of the things you wanted to see? Patient: I think we did. Family Member: Yeah. We did. It was nice. (Laughter) Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: All right. Good. That’s good. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Well, today, we’ve got to sort of talk about what next. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, I just reviewed, again, all the scans from a month ago or so. So really what we see in you is all of the disease seems to be in the bone. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So you don’t have any really anything in lymph nodes, or liver, or lung, which is, you know, good and bad. Uh, the bad part of it is, you know, it’s hard to kind of get a good sense of how things work in the bone because the scans we do are, uh, mostly telling us new spots in the bone. But they, we can’t really measure things getting bigger or smaller. Patient: Um hum.

Patient: Oh. Doctor: Now one of the things that I also wanted to discuss with you was some um of the clinical trials that we’re doing. In other words, research studies – Patient: Uh huh. DOC - investigating new approaches which might not be approved for prostate cancer. Doctor: For prostate cancer. And one of the um trials that we’re doing, which we are quite excited about is this concept of using high doses of testosterone as a therapy for prostate cancer. Patient: As a therapy? Now testosterone feeds the cancer, correct? Doctor: Correct. I knew you’d say that. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So this is quite a paradoxical approach. Patient: Okay, good. Doctor: And it turns out that you’re absolutely right. We’ve known for a long time for about seventy years that testosterone can feed into your prostate cancer. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: However, we have recently discovered in the last three or four years that they can take a patient who has had low testosterone levels for a very long time they call that hormone-resistant prostate cancer or castration-resistant prostate cancer is another term Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Uh he’s my oncologist Patient: I’m presuming no. where I uh had the scans done Doctor: I’ll ask about it. My sense is don’t order a lot of those tests because Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: If you not having any bone or physical symptoms If it meets the threshold, they can give you a pill Patient: Yeah, yeah, at the same time, so Doctor: Yeah so hopefully that will put money in the bank and back in two days for your calcium and doing all the right thigns to keep your bones strong. Patient: Yeah Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Great I’ll let you head out and uh we’ll get these things off Patient: Happy New Year!

Patient: Okay, so. Doctor: Okay. Patient: All right. Doctor: Well, good. It was nice to see you. I'm glad we had a chance to chat and you know, if it's good then call M___ and I’ll tell her to be on the lookout. Patient: Okay. So it's up to me to call her and let her know. Doctor: Well I’ll have her call you too. But that way, you know that at your convenience if you're at work, and she calls you that you can call her back. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Oh, good. Okay, cool. Sit tight here and I have a feeling, wait, wait. Go ahead. See that I knew this young lady would be waiting on me.

Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We also sort of know what side effects you’re going to experience to sort of see whether you can tolerate this. We have to adjust the doses about that. So that’s an approved drug that’s known to extend survival if people get the drugs, tolerate the drugs, respond to the drugs. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know those people can do well compared to those who don’t respond or don’t get the drug. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So chemo would be something that you know it could be given here, it could be given there, but it’s standard treatment. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We have a clinical trial where we’re giving the chemotherapy and everybody gets an infusion two to three times a week. So- Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: for someone coming from F___ may it may be too much to come in here that often, but we’re giving Vitamin C to half the people and half the people don’t because some data says that Vitamin C may reduce the side effects of the chemotherapy and also help the benefit. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: But we don’t know that. It could be just folly; it could be the truth-

Patient: I’m, I’m interested in. Doctor: Let me, uh- Patient: And plus it also, it, its information that could be useful to maybe help other people. You know? Doctor: Yeah. Let me find out about the, the biopsy requirements today, uh. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: I know we have some trials that if you have bone, they do not, you can’t be on the trial, because they just don’t get the tissue. Patient: Right. Doctor: So they don’t want to, uh, subject you to, you know, have a needle stuck in your bone if it’s not going to be helpful. Patient: Right. Doctor: And so, but the trial requires the tissue, because they’re trying to study how the new drug affects the tissue in some way. So let me, let me look into that, uh, to see if any of the trials allow bone only. The only trials we have for hormonal treatment are with Xtandi right now, uh, not with the other drug. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So, if it looks like you can’t, if it looks like you would fit on the trial, we can talk about them more. If, if it looks like the bone thing is going to eliminate that-

Patient: It’s not bad is it? Doctor: I mean I don’t think it’s worse, but it’s not getting better. Family Member: So would that lesion affect his legs also, is it the same stem you know nerve system? Doctor: You know usually not. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Because I mean hopefully – the arm nerves are on the outside. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Okay so the leg nerves are running further down. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But I mean technically yes, if there is a clean total cut of the cord or major pressure at that level, it can affect the arms and the legs. Family Member: Yeah. Patient: Because I have pain walking upstairs. Doctor: Sort of the Christopher Reeve’s spot –

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I’m not sure there’s more side effects; it’s just sort of we just have to put them out there, talk about them more. Patient: Yes. Doctor: You know chemotherapy has its own set of side effects Patient: Right. Doctor: But we have what the known benefits potentially are, whereas the clinical trials—we don’t know the benefits. Family Member: Yeah, uh hum. Doctor: We know a lot about the side effects. Family Member: Well with having chemotherapy, would that be, I know it’s not the same drug, but the same effect like I had chemotherapy for breast cancer? Doctor: Yes, we use one drug. We use Taxotere. So I don’t which ones you got. Family Member: I had Adriamycin and Cytoxan. Doctor: Yeah, it’s a little bit different.

Family Member: His last PSA do you have the results of that? Because we didn’t get uh… Where did you have that done? Doctor: I only have CBC’s from outside, so I think - Patient: I had I had a PSA done. Doctor: - today’s PSA is going to be your one in a long time. Family Member: Okay well he had one… Doctor: Because when they did it in F____ all they did is only blood counts right? Patient: Uh, yeah. Yeah, B___ City. Family Member: Yeah – oh – I don’t know. Doctor: Are you saying he did a PSA in between in F____? Family Member: I thought so or in B____, yeah. Patient: I got to check. I’m not sure. I thought C___ had it. Doctor: Okay because the only results I have is all the blood counts. Family Member: Okay.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.strongly agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::strongly agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White
